text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^3 \rightarrow \mathbb R^4[/mathjaxinline] be the linear transformation with standard matrix
How many solutions does the equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline] have?

solution.font:
Matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] row reduces to
[mathjax]\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 0& 0& 0 \\ 0& 0& 0 \end{array} \right].[/mathjax] Thus, when augmented with the zero vector, there are infinitely many solutions. This also tells us that [mathjaxinline]\mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline] is not the only solution to [mathjaxinline]Ax=\mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline], and thus [mathjaxinline]\mathrm{Ker}(T) \neq \{ \mathbf{0}\}[/mathjaxinline]. Since [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] sends multiple vectors to [mathjaxinline]\mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] does not satisfy the definition of into.
